statement:
Let $f:\mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{R}$ be a continuous probability density
function. Let $X_1, \ldots, X_n$ be random variables with density $f$
and with covariance matrix ${\mathbf{K}}$,
$K_{ij} = {\mathrm{cov}}(X_i, X_j)$. Let $\phi$ be the distribution of
the with mean ${\mathbf{0}}$ and covariance matrix ${\mathbf{K}}$. Then
the Gaussian distribution maximizes the differential entropy for a given
covariance matrix ${\mathbf{K}}$. That is, $h(\phi) \ge h(f)$.
names: Gaussian distribution maximizes entropy for given covariance
